question: In Nature journal's Scientific Reports conference proceedings from 2012, in the article that did not mention plasmons or plasmonics, what nano-compound is studied? Don't use the prefix nano in your answer if there is one.

trajectory.question: In Nature journal's Scientific Reports conference proceedings from 2012, in the article that did not mention plasmons or plasmonics, what nano-compound is studied? Don't use the prefix nano in your answer if there is one.

args.query: Scientific Reports 2012 conference proceedings 'did not mention plasmons' 'plasmonics' which article 'conference proceedings' 2012 site:nature.com 'Scientific Reports'

tool_executed.name: search_with_content
tool_executed.result:
Found 1 web results with content:

1. Surface plasmon resurrection | Nature Photonics
   URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/nphoton.2012.296
   Site: nature.com
   Summary: by N PHOTONICS · 2012 · Cited by 8 — Most of these papers would not be considered particularly relevant to surface plasmon photonics or plasmonics. In the 1980s and 1990s, there ...
   Content: Surface plasmon resurrection | Nature Photonics Skip to main content Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain
            the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in
            Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles
            and JavaScript. Advertisement View all journals Search Log in Content Explore content About the journal Publish with us Sign up for alerts RSS feed nature nature photonics editorials article Surface plasmon resurrection Download PDF Download PDF Editorial Published: 05 November 2012 Surface plasmon resurrection Nature Photonics volume 6 , page 707 ( 2012 ) Cite this article 31k Accesses 31 Citations 4 Altmetric Metrics details The realization that coupling of photons to charges at metal interfaces allows subdiffraction-limit localization of light has revived the field of surface plasmons. How long will it last? This month, Nature Photonics presents a focus issue dedicated to the field of surface plasmon polariton photonics, or 'plasmonics'. The term plasmonics might be new, but the interaction of light with charges at surfaces is not. Joachim Krenn, from the University of Graz, Austria, and one of the founders of the modern field of plasmonics, mentions in an interview on page 714 that people were formulating ideas over 100 years ago that still hold relevance to plasmonics researchers today. The coupling of light to charges at metal surfaces is also cited as being utilized hundreds (or even thousands) of years before that, but the science at the time was not known and the crediting of some cases (for example the coloration of some particular historical artefacts) to plasmonics may be incorrect. Following the early work of Maxwell Garnett and others in about 1904, there were periods of revival in the field every ten years or so. Using a few relevant se

tool_executed.result:
Found 1 web results with content:

1. Diamond photonic crystal slab: Leaky modes and modified ...
   URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/srep00914
   Site: nature.com
   Summary: by L Ondič · Cited by 27 — Here we present a detailed study of the leaky modes of a nanocrystalline diamond (NCD) PhC slab by investigating polarization resolved photonic band diagrams.
   Content: Diamond photonic crystal slab: Leaky modes and modified photoluminescence emission of surface-deposited quantum dots | Scientific Reports Skip to main content Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain
            the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in
            Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles
            and JavaScript. Advertisement View all journals Search Log in Content Explore content About the journal Publish with us Sign up for alerts RSS feed nature scientific reports conference proceedings article Diamond photonic crystal slab: Leaky modes and modified photoluminescence emission of surface-deposited quantum dots Download PDF Download PDF Conference Proceeding Open access Published: 03 December 2012 Diamond photonic crystal slab: Leaky modes and modified photoluminescence emission of surface-deposited quantum dots Lukáš Ondič 1 , 2 , 3 , Oleg Babchenko 1 , Marián Varga 1 , Alexander Kromka 1 , Jiří Čtyroký 4 & … Ivan Pelant 1 Show authors Scientific Reports volume 2 , Article number: 914 ( 2012 ) Cite this article 54k Accesses 19 Citations 5 Altmetric Metrics details Subjects Materials science Optical physics Optics and photonics Optical spectroscopy Abstract Detailed analysis of a band diagram of a photonic crystal (PhC) slab prepared on a nano-diamond layer is presented. Even though the PhC is structurally imperfect, the existence of leaky modes, determined both theoretically and experimentally in the broad spectral region, implies that an efficient light interaction with a material periodicity occurs in the sample. It is shown that the luminescence emission spectrum of a light source placed directly on the PhC surface can be modified by employing the optical modes of the studied structure. We stress also the impact of intrinsic optical losses of the nan

args.query: site:nature.com "Efficient light coupling for optically excited high-density metallic nanotip arrays" Scientific Reports 2012

tool_executed.name: search_with_content
tool_executed.result:
Found 1 web results with content:

1. Efficient light coupling for optically excited high-density ...
   URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/srep00915
   Site: nature.com
   Summary: by A Mustonen · Cited by 34 — Efficient light coupling for optically excited high-density metallic nanotip arrays ... Scientific Reports volume 2, Article number: 915 (2012) ...
   Content: Efficient light coupling for optically excited high-density metallic nanotip arrays | Scientific Reports Skip to main content Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain
            the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in
            Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles
            and JavaScript. Advertisement View all journals Search Log in Content Explore content About the journal Publish with us Sign up for alerts RSS feed nature scientific reports conference proceedings article Efficient light coupling for optically excited high-density metallic nanotip arrays Download PDF Download PDF Conference Proceeding Open access Published: 03 December 2012 Efficient light coupling for optically excited high-density metallic nanotip arrays Anna Mustonen 1 , Paul Beaud 2 , Eugenie Kirk 1 , Thomas Feurer 3 & … Soichiro Tsujino 1 Show authors Scientific Reports volume 2 , Article number: 915 ( 2012 ) Cite this article 23k Accesses 26 Citations 2 Altmetric Metrics details Subjects Applied physics Optical physics Optics and photonics Ultrafast photonics Abstract Ultrafast electron pulses can be produced from sharp metallic tips illuminated by femtosecond near infrared laser pulses. Use of an array of metallic nanotips for high charge bunch generation and accelerator applications is also feasible but the small fraction of the emitter tip area limits the quantum efficiency. We therefore propose a submicron-pitch, high-density nanotip array device with a gate electrode, that can support surface-plasmon polaritons. From a theoretical analysis for a device with an asymmetric emitter position, a factor ~30 increased array quantum efficiency is demonstrated. Similar content being viewed by others Sub-wavelength patterned pulse laser lithography for efficient fabrication of large-area metasu

trajectory.actor_reasoning:
The 2012 Scientific Reports conference proceedings include four articles; three explicitly mention plasmon or plasmonic. The remaining one, “Diamond photonic crystal slab...,” studies nanocrystalline diamond. 

FINAL ANSWER: diamond

1. Layered plasmonic cloaks to tailor the optical scattering at ...
   URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/srep00912
   Site: nature.com
   Summary: by F Monticone · Cited by 57 — Layered plasmonic cloaks to tailor the optical scattering at the nanoscale. F. Monticone,; C. Argyropoulos &; A. Alù. Scientific Reports ...
   Content: Layered plasmonic cloaks to tailor the optical scattering at the nanoscale | Scientific Reports Skip to main content Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain
            the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in
            Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles

Advertisement View all journals Search Log in Content Explore content About the journal Publish with us Sign up for alerts RSS feed nature scientific reports conference proceedings article Layered plasmonic cloaks to tailor the optical scattering at the nanoscale Download PDF Download PDF Conference Proceeding Open access Published: 03 December 2012 Layered plasmonic cloaks to tailor the optical scattering at the nanoscale F. Monticone 1 , C. Argyropoulos 1 & A. Alù 1 Scientific Reports volume 2 , Article number: 912 ( 2012 ) Cite this article 45k Accesses 46 Citations Metrics details Subjects Condensed-matter physics Nanoparticles Optical materials Optical materials and structures Abstract We discuss the rich scattering features offered by thin and thick plasmonic layers covering dielectric nanoparticles and their potential optical applications. The frequency position of scattering dips and peaks may be controlled to a large degree using plasmonic layers, which may dramatically vary the total scattering signature in the frequency range of interest. We show that complex and exotic spectra may be obtained using a single composite nanosphere, including dipole-dipole Fano resonances and electromagnetic induced transparency effects. The described phenomena are observable at any angle of observation, in the total scattering cross section and for realistic plasmonic materials, since they are based on purely dipolar fields. Enhanced field amplitudes are associated with these anomalous scattering

The 2012 Scientific Reports conference proceedings include four articles; three explicitly mention plasmon or plasmonic. The remaining one, “Diamond photonic crystal slab...,” studies nanocrystalline diamond.
